title: Replacement jacks for Early Music Shop Harpsichord from 1976
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have restored another harpsichord! It was made in 1976, then recently given to me by the owner because it wasn't playable any more. I've made 3D printed jacks to replace the old wooden ones, and damper holders for the 4 foot stop. It now plays well, and will soon be painted in the 18 century style (red with gold leaf). You can hear it, here: -
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3703861/EMS_harpsichord.mp3 Soon, I'll add 61 solenoids to automate it! Notice that the white notes have white jacks, and the back notes have black jacks! Pointless but fun! Confusingly perhaps, the white notes on this instrument are actually black and the back notes are all white! If you want to know more, email me at [email protected]

Print the parts 100% ABS plastic. Save the brass jack bottoms and re-use these. Obtain the little screws and the tongues and plectra from http://www.hubharp.com/parts.htm. If unsure which, mention my name. He'll remember - I did this twice already. Some jacks will need to be sandpapered to fit as the slots are not perfectly consistent in size. Important: - The jacks' rail needs to be about 6 mm higher than was designed, to accommodate the plectra adjustment screws which were not there in the original version. This is simple to achieve: Just drill its mounting holes a bit higher up inside the cabinet. The rail will still be clear of the lid. Let me know if you get it working! Malcolm

title: JR compatible module enclosure for RC radio Walkera WK-1001

description.text:
Do you own an old RC radio Walkera WK-1001 with a 35, 40 or 72 Mhz module and want to use it in the 2,4GHz band?
You can, by simply replacing the radio module on the back with a JR compatible one, but.... They are too big and don't fit! This is a workaround to substitute the enclosures of the JR and compatible modules, that are too big, with one that can accomodate the electronics and fits into the WALKERA WK-1001 module bay, without any sanding that, after, makes impossible to resell the modules due their ugly appearance... The .STL file include its supporting material, as you can see evidenced in green in the second image of the enclosure, so it does not require any other support built by the 'slicing' software. That material consists in thin walls (0,2mm thick), that must be removed with a sharp cutter (see the 3rd and 4th picture). Be careful when removing the material under the retainers, that can break easily.
It's a good choice, after removing the supporting material, to brush both sides of the retainers with a little paintbrush lightly wet with acetone, to make them more robust, obviously after printing it in ABS. Also, you can adjust a little the rectangular aperture on the bottom, from which the module accepts the five pins of the radio. Inside, there are three supports with holes where to screw the lid of the module. These can be adjusted in height at need by cutting away the excess of material. Thanks for reading!

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

0,2mm/layer

40%

description.text: Since MB will not sell or send out extra top ends to fix the 1000s of smart extruders they have out there I decided to make something close to what they have done. It is still in the design phase and will also require you to use a 608ZZ bearing that can be obtained at mcmaster carr or many 3d printer parts sites. Any suggestions let me know.  Models are updated. The top end is now in place and after two successful prints I feel pretty good about the design. You will probably have to add a spring as shown in order to help return the tubing guide (I have to do that with the MB top end as well.) I hope this works great for you. So nice to be able to put the top back on our printer now!

Collaborative, student-designed periodic table. 
Each student was assigned an element to research and design on Tinkercad, and then each element was 3D printed in 2 colors.
This table makes a great interactive classroom set, as magnet tape easily adheres to the plastic, allowing it to be displayed on a whiteboard and easily moved around.  Print multiple copies of each element to create molecules and materials!

description.text: New filament spools from a different supplier were wider and could not fit in my original/ old design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773044) so I made version 2, here, that would fit multiple reels in a single box. Added a simplified filament dispenser opening that prints a lot faster. But requires a pair of M3*8mm screws to secure, and a short PTFE tube to provide a smooth flow. The spools are held by a 1.5 inch PVC tuning, mounted on both sides of the box with M3*8mm screws. Spool separators prevent/ minimise spool contact (inspired by a design I saw on Thinginverse, but cannot recall where). Suggestion: Mount spools in opposite directions, mount PTFE holders in alternate top/down configuration to prevent spool entanglement. Works for me. Hygrometer mount can be found at my original design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773044)

comments.text: Cool! Let us know how you get on with that. I don't recommend Ziplock bags unless you're prepared to take the reels out every time you use them and then dry them again, and repeated de and re-hydration can't be good for filament. I tried printing out of press-seal Ziplock bags before all these, but the occasional filament catching the soft bag gave me nightmares.
comments.author: pcdupuis

comments.text: This looks great! If you get reusable desiccant, you can just reconstitute it instead of relying on new filament purchases.
comments.author: Snortimer

comments.text: I'm "drying" my gel packs in my electronic dry cabinet :) That works great, no fuss and risk associated with frying or drying desiccant gel in the microwave or a frying pan. Before I started this (and the original airtight box: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773044) I did consider using dry cabinet units but that was overkill. The rate of decay is so low I've not had to recharge my gel packs from my original project 6 months ago as the hygrometers still show ~60% RH.
comments.author: Snortimer

comments.text: Maybe not all ovens will, but our house oven can be set as low as 180F - which is a great temperature for drying... put in your filament and/or dessicant for 2 hours and it comes out dry, but not destroyed.

comments.text:
@tasimp, t3rry: Container/ bucket is "Toyogo 9901" See: http://www.toyogogroup.com/storage-containers.html
It is a shop in Singapore and Malaysia, not sure if they ship overseas but for this, you need a box about this size: 34cm (W/ L - across), 26cm depth and width. The reels are 20cm diameter and 7cm high/ thick.
Best to bring a reel along when you shop, and make sure there is enough room to roll the reel (and close the lid!) but not too big you waste space.

This spool holder contains the following qualities:
Stability: The spool doesn't derail or fall over.
Flexibility: It can bend so it adapt to any irregularities you might have in your table or wherever you place it on.
Strength: You can stand on it without breaking it (don't jump on it).
Simplicity: You just need 2 parts to support your spool, obviously fully printable.
Economy: The design is minimalistic, saving filament and time.
You don't need any bearings or other stuff to let your spool roll with little resistance. The plastic creates very little resistance with the plastic of the spool and the extruder can easily pull the spool around.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm - 0.3mm

Infill:

(0%) - 25% - 100%

Notes: Flip the model 90 degrees on the X-axis.
Scale the model up by 10 to make it the right size. 0.3mm is possible, but too rough. Not recommended. 0.2mm is the best compromise between printing speed and quality. 0.1mm the smoothest finish, but not necessary. For 0% infill, use: Shell thickness: 0.8mm Top/Bottom Thickness: 1.2mm Otherwise I advise a 25% infill
Printing time is precious, aswell as the expensive filament. I believe that some things can also be functional without being so large, and don't have to be nice to do the trick.

comments.text: I read your comments on PHIL and agree in principle (simple == good, print time & filament should be minimized) so I said, well, I wonder if he followed up on his complaints by posting his own design. And you did! Awesome! So I printed a pair of these, but they aren't working for me. The spool will drag the supports as the extruder feeds, and it simply rolls off if I block them from sliding.
comments.author: tastewar

comments.text: On other holders I use Teflon tape to make it better gliding. I use the typical tape for water installations. Maybe this helps here too.
comments.author: tastewar

comments.text: It works for me, but only because the filament goes straight up into the extruder. If it wouldn't go straight up I would have the same problem as you have, since I didn't test it the way you use it. I might change that some time later on :). Thanks for the feedback!

description.text:
Variable plate cell that can be used with the 8XA experiment.
Fit easily in 85 mm diameter jar.

It is designed for 60 mm plate width. ( I use 60 x 120 mm 304L plates)
You will need 4 smooth rods 3 mm diameter.
1 x M5 threaded rod (lenght depends of your plate size)
6 x - M5 nuts
4 x - M3 x 15 mm screws + Washers
2 x Small screws to block the fishinf line in place.
Some fishing line (fluorocarbon works well) Use a 3.1 or 3.2mm drill bit to have an effective guide with the 3mm smooth rods (Too much play and it will not work properly)

title: Ciclop Camera Holder with No Supports

description.text: This is the same exact Camera Holder provided by BQ labs for the Ciclop 3D Scanner project with the exception of included supports. I found the supports to print poorly on my printer. I edited the source files (https://github.com/bqlabs/ciclop/tree/master/step) in Fusion 360 and making the STL available here for others who prefer their slicer to setup supports. I hope others find this useful.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

User/Printer Preference

Infill:

User/Printer Preference

Notes: I've successfully printed this on a Printrbot Metal Plus with the following Cura settings:
  • 1.75 mm PLA
  • .4 mm Nozzle
  • 20% Fill
  • 12 Line Brim
  • Support Type: Everywhere
  • Grid, Overhang at 60, Fill 15%
  • X/Y Distance .7 mm
  • Z Distance .15 mm
Fusion 360

title: Pyramidal accoustic insulation foam,  glueable wall mount

description.text:
apart from looking rather funky, it features a hole to put in the nail/screw for the wall, while the octupus legs are for glueing. The problem is that one still needs special glue, to get things to stick on the pyramidic foam plates.
The pyramids enable sound waves to be coupled into the foam, where they are absobred due to the unelastic foam. Similar to pyramidal anti reflex coatings for optical devices, e.g. solar cells.

description.text:
bonjour,
ayant eu des difficultés à régler la position des laser verticalement et en même temps pour qu'ils se croisent au milieu du plateau, j'ai fait un remix de la pièce Laser Holder.
après quelques ennuis d'impression du a la petite taille de la piece ronde j'ai imaginé la faire en aluminum.
je met en liens une méthode alternative de tenue des laser. en 2 pieces New laser holder for easier setting laser position.. 30/9-2015 change of round part, will have to screw into the plastic and not using a nut.
part is too small. I started to make the rounded part in aluminium in case to screw laser and fix it vertically

title: Printrbot Plus Vert. Shaft Extruder Mount for Bowden

description.text: While converting my Printrbot Plus to use Bowden tubes (dual extruders look out!), I decided that I wanted the extruder to sit at the top of the Z-Axis shaft rather than stand alone. It is paired with my Ubis Hot End Bowden Mount. The Bowden tube gets pretty bent when the X- axis is homed and at the top of the Z-travel. It still works, but the additional friction doesn't help the ooze. Next design will put the extruder centered (and higher) on a cross bar linking the Z shafts. This model is for the Printrbot Plus 12mm Z shaft, the OpenSCAD file has a parameter line: __printr_shaft = 6; // plus = 6, lc = 4__ . This is the shaft radius. Change it to 4 for the 8mm LC shafts. I made this with measurements from the Printrbot and pneufit adapter: SPC-06-01 Pneumatic Push to Connect Fitting. This fitting uses a British Standard Pipe Taper Thread R1/8". Tap size is 8.4mm for this thread, but I'm 'self' tapping with the thread itself into the plastic. I'm using 9.45mm for the base and 9.15 for the tip (it tapers.) I bought these from eBay
I printed this (using a Bowden setup!) at .8 infill.

comments.text: What kind of pipe you use? it is a special one or anything I could find on a hardware store?
comments.author: FherraZ

comments.text: The material is called PTFE (Polytetrafluorethylene). It's a non-slip, rugged tube available from industrial suppliers, amazon or ebay. (http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss_1?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=ptfe%20tube)http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb.... It might be available at a well stocked hardware store, but most people buy it online. There are special fittings (usually called 'pneufit') that are generally used to mount it. I have more detail at http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=21&t=4112&sid=d4eb2df9345a2ac483e13d14bca4e979http://www.printrbottalk.com/f....
comments.author: FherraZ

comments.text: Thank you for your answer, I don't live on a "online" friendly country and so it is difficult for me to get hardware this way, I have to go to my local hardware store and see if I get lucky.
comments.author: tdeagan

comments.text: Good luck!  The material of the tube isn't critical, it's just that PTFE is extremely slippery (as well as chemically resistant and other nice to have qualities).
comments.author: FherraZ

comments.text: Thank you for the tip, I have followed the links you have for the tubes and I have found other sizes too, I don't know which will work better, here are some size examples:
comments.author: tdeagan

comments.text: The inner diameter should be slightly larger than the filament.  I see most folk consistently using the 6mm OD, 4mm ID for 3mm filament.  The fittings need to be matched to the outer diameter of the tube used (or else the press fitting mechanism won't work.)
comments.author: FherraZ

A quick necklace design based on the Catwoman character from DC Comics.
Measures 40mm on the X axis and 3.46mm on the Z axis.
Printed mine at .2mm layer height with an infill of 30% at 40mm/s utilizing ABS. Gave it a quick wet sand with 600 grit and then two coats of high gloss lacquer.

Doesn't Matter

No

First did the design up in Photoshop. Then I exported it to Illustrator and created a SVG image. I imported the SVG into Blender and converted it into a mesh object. Then I selected the top vertices and extruded on the Z axis. Once that was done I saved as an STL and opened it in Cura where I set the dimensions. Next re-saved that model and then uploaded it to cloud.netfabb.com to make sure it was fixed properly. Lastly I opened the new saved file back in Cura and printed the piece.

author: chaggarty

description.text:
So I got my MakerBot working and I realized how hard it is to measure things with just a ruler. So I decided to design myself some digital calipers. 
It is made of 2 parts, a top and a bottom. The bottom half has a overhang on it so that it can enclose the top half. So its a good idea to have a cooling fan on for this print. 
The top half should just slide right into the bottom half. 
Enjoy.
Features a cover to prevent dust getting into the earbuds.
Print!

NOTE: On Aug 30, 2013 I updated the file. I extended the end just a bit. I found it a bit tight on more recent Octave reels, so I gave it just a bit more room.  
A hybrid spool holder that will accommodate THREE different spool types. This now accommodates the wide Octave spools, the Afinia Premium black plastic spools and the Afinia Value Line cardboard spools without swapping out the holder. This is designed to work with Octave's Universal Spindle Adapter, found on Octave's site.  
Please feel free to suggest alterations if it doesn't work perfectly.  
This version now has a slightly stronger buttress in order to handle the slightly thinner holder where the Afinia Value Line reel sits.  
Each reel slides down into its own gravity well, and stays there adequately.  
I hope you like it.

I downloaded and printed the Octave Universal Spindle Adapter kit including the Afinia and Octave spool holders. I used those as test items, then made some measurements and modeled (from scratch) a new holder that would accommodate both reels, rather than having to swap them out.   
It works by pushing the wider Octave spools closer to the base, keeping it off the indentation. And for the narrower spools, you let it slip into the indentation which holds it rather well.

description.text: spells my initials left, down, and diagonal.

The Y pulleys of the Fabrikator don't have any bearings. This thing can solve that issue. It fits 5x13x4mm bearings like these: http://nl.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-Skate-board-bearing-695ZZ-695-2Z-695-Z-5x13x4-mm-2015-new-coming-shoe-bearing/32380092967.html?ws_ab_test=201556_10,201527_4_71_72_73_74_75,201409_1 The part is split into 3 parts to make it easier to print. The existing roller and axle can be re used. The grooves in the axle are 1mm too close to eachother, so only one clip can be used. Use a drop of threadlock on the other side to keep it in pace. Alternatively, you can glue the pulley to the axle, glue on one half of the bearing holders and attach the other one with a self tapping screw. I changed the design to make it shorter so we can have more build volume! The taller version is also there to download as the stock belts are too short for the short pulley block.

title: LED Light Bar for Raspberry Pi Camera Mount on Prusa i3

description.text: This is a light bar that mounts to the raspberry pi mount in thing 504823, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:504823. The LEDs provide sufficient light to see the part being printed when using the camera even if the printer is in a dark room. Even if it is an room with lighting, the LEDs light up the part being printed without any shadows. It holds 6 LEDs, they are wired in two sets of 3. Each set is in series with a current limiting resistor, I used 200 ohms. Each white LED has a voltage drop of about 3V so with 3 in series and the current limiting resistor it runs well off of the main 12V supply. The two sets of series LEDs are connected in parallel to the 12V power supply. To make things neat and prevent any short circuits I used some heat shrink tubing to cover the wiring in the case. You use the parts from the thing 504823, except that you need to replace the bracket that holds the raspberry pi box with the one here. The LED light bar mounts below the camera. There are two covers: a left and right that slide onto the light to cover the LEDs and the wiring. The new and modified parts are all yellow parts in the photos, the original camera mount is printed in red.

I printed at 0.3mm layer height, 0.4 infill, 2 perimeters with standard printrbot. My printer calibration is not perfect so I have added the dwg (Acad Inventor) files encase any changes need to be made.

title: Western Digital My Passport Ultra Dock with USB hub.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a dock I made for my external hard drive. I also added a slot for a 4 port USB 3.0 hub. Other hubs may work but the one I am using is: [Link to Amazon] The area where the HDD docks has a small hole to allow a right angle USB 3 B Micro cable. The area to the left of the USB hub has enough room to route the built in cable. EDIT: I have updated the design to fix some issues that Bartleby pointed out.One of the problems was that the hole for the HDD USB was over by 4mm. I moved that and added supports to hold the HDD. Hopefully everything should be in line now. I also changed the file type. The new file type is a ASCII STL file with millimeters as the units.

Assembly MAKE SURE YOU TEST FIT EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU HOT GLUE ANYTHING!!!
You may need to sand different parts of the build to make them fit properly.

  • Take a right angle USB 3.0 Micro B connector and hot glue it into place inside the hole for the HDD. You may want to connect the cable to the HDD to line it up. Be careful not to get hot glue on the HDD or inside the USB cable, as you do not want it to be stuck.

  • Route the cable for the HDD through the back cable channel.

  • Route the cable for the USB hub through the front cable channel.

  • You may want to place some tape or hot clue on the cables to hold them in place while you attach the bottom piece.

  • Line up the bottom of the dock with the top of the dock. (You may want to use hot glue to make sure they stay together. If not, the holes should be tight enough to keep it in place.)

  • Once you have connected the bottom piece to the top, you may want to use hot glue or double sided tape to make sure the USB hub is stable.

  • Optionally, you may want to find some rubber feet to use on the bottom of the dock to keep it from moving around.

author: joris

remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: Generate wood patterns with temperature changes

description.text: I've been experimenting with some wood filament from Formfutura (http://www.formfutura.com/) and Mooncactus has created a grain script in python that converts a gcode file into one that simulates woodgrain. Sadly I couldn't get the resultant file to be accepted in Makerware, so I set about fixing it, crudely, but as it turns out, effectively. I made a VB script that runs under MS Word that takes the original gcode file, finds any 'Slice' entries and inserts one of Mooncactus's variable temperature settings underneath it. So every layer is printed at a different temperature from the last one, some changes are gradual, some more dramatic. You can see the difference it makes in the two owls (made by Satoshi).

To use it, first generate the gcode file in Makerware by selecting File, Export, Export to file and choose the 'GCode Slice only (*.gcode)' option.  Put the resultant file (eg 'owl.gcode') together with the 'temp-vals.txt' file into whichever folder you want to use and then open the 'woodgrain.docm' file.  
A box opens up asking you to click the button to select the gcode file you want to add grain to.  Once you choose the file, the script runs and closes itself.  Shut down Word and you will find a new file in the folder called 'owlgrain.gcode'  ie there's a new file called what the old one was called except for having 'grain' added.  
Then, in Makerware, chose File, Make from file and select the '*grain.gcode file and off you go.

title: 1920'sTruck and Circus Wheel with Solid Rubber Tire

description.text: Before 1922 when Firestone started manufacturing the balloon tire, trucks ran on solid rubber tires as modeled on this wheel. This type of wheel would have been common on early Mack and other trucks.  The Cole Bros. Circus was somewhere on the west coast in 1936 or 1937 when owners, Zack Terrell and Jess Atkins,bought as many as would fit on their circus train and loaded them in every available spot.. Probably got a bargain as the truckers were converting to the balloons. Of course Terrell and Atkins got the last laugh when tire shortages due to WW II caused all sorts of problems for the balloon tire people. The Circus preserved these wheels well beyond their general usage.

The wheel was modeled at 3/4 inch = 1 foot.
Printed flat on the back side it requires no raft or support.
There is a dimple at the center on the back to serve as a starter for drilling an appropriate hole for an axle.
Two wheels can be glued back to back representing the double wheels used at the rear, heaviest load, of many trucks.

comments.text:
Made this and found one challenge: The ram head for the plunger (002) would not print right. all I got was a pile of spaghetti. I spent some time adjusting the printer, etc which didn't help at all. Finally I rotated the ram head image and discovered that there is a little "dibble" in the center of the bottom. That dibble holds the part slightly above the print plate. Hence the mess. After I rotated the ram head so that one of its rectangular sides was on the build plate, it printed well. (I used a raft.)
The tube (003) printed correctly and it looks as though it will work fine. I haven't tried to print the handle (001) because I plan to use a piece of wooden dowel.
The dibble is a nice feature which will press a little hole for the seed in the exact center of the top of the soil block.

description.text:
My first scratch "thing" very pleased with the 15deg mount, recommend printing it on the side. The lens protector is basic but it doesn't interfere with the video or picture, does stick in-front of the lens and is a tight fit. The camera is very long and is sticking out from the mount, it also slips from zip ties on crashes,
The lens protector has holes to connect a zip tie through and then connect the protector zip tie to the mount zip tie with a zip tie of course :) A good velcro strap like scorpion is also good, the mount has the space.

author: sevet

description.text:
I searched an stand for my glasses for not always have to put them loose aside my bed while sleeping.
You can glue this stand with double-sided tape on a smooth surface and put your glasses on. Also without folding them. Especially interesting for people with fixed temples. This is my first CAD design and i put the .ipt online so you can change sizes on your own. I hope this helps some of you. Keep in mind that your glasses should be in balance because they are held by only one position. Glasses are usually symmetrical so it should be no problem. But simply check it yourself by putting your glasses with the "nose bridge" on your finger. Let me know if you have suggestions. EDIT: Please check the "_smooth" - Version. I added some smoother rounding on the base and tip. See my blog: http://konkludenz.de/

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: I printed this stand with an "Ultimaker Original" with the following settings: layer thickness: 0.08
outer thickness: 0.8
bottom/top thickness: 0.8
infill: 20%
speed: 30mm/s
temp: 210°C It printed round about 40min. It feels quite stable and is in use :)
